reviewText: I'm a huge fan of this brilliant series, so it was a no-brainer to get it when the price on Amazon got down to far less than $1.00 per episode.The big unknown when you purchase these boxed sets of an entire TV series is what might be given up -e.g., original music or unwelcome "enhancements", syndication (editing), etc.  Admittedly I've only watched the first three episodes, but thus far I am so impressed.  The menus are clean, easy to read, no sappy, annoying background music or animation.  The recording quality of the original programs is superb, with Rod Serling's narratives and even the CBS logo and title fonts still exactly as they were on the original broadcasts - not with 15 more copyright/production logos after the first.  The bonus narratives by the original actors from the episodes are a nice touch too - again, not overdone or overdramatic.  This show is so outstanding and creative on its own that any "fluff" would be a distraction.The box sets had a minimal amount of packaging and that impressed me too.  The 28 DVDs are secure, yet they take up a minimal amount of space.If you love this show as I do, this set is a must have for your collection.  Highly recommended!
summary: Best-packaged DVD Set I've Ever Purchased

reviewText: I was watching a Christmas-New Years marathon of the Twilight Zone last year; and was pleasantly surprised.  Many shows that I watched and loved in 1960s haven't aged well.  The Twilight Zone: the Complete Definitive Collection is not one them.Even though the story lines are tied in with Supernatural/Paranormal/Horror/SciFi, it is solid plot lines, acting, characterization and well timed lighting in a Black and White setting.  It's easy to suspend your disbelief with the lack of special effects.  There are a lot of famous actors before they were....  Some players are what you would expect.  William Shatner is well William Shatner in good stories.  For those who remember Elizabeth Montgomery as perky Samantha in "Bewitched", she makes you forget that in "Two" as a grim, tough soldier.  Jack Klugman and Jonathan Winters make impressive dramatic appearances as well.  Even in the Monster of the Week type of shows, your special effects spoiled mind can get past that with the ironic plots.  In "One For the Angels", a particular favorite, they opted for no effects at all.  What could have been the MOW was an ordinary man in a suit.  It made for even more apprehension.  Our main character could see our ordinary man in the suit, everyone else could not except at certain times.  It had a theme that's common in TWZ of unintended consequences and the main character dealing with those.  Without giving anything away it was a sweet story.Some reviewers may find this a minus; there are few bonus materials compared to other sets.  I also found the 4th season to be the weakest because of the hour long format.  The stories seemed to drawn out and seemed to have too much filler.  With TWZ less is more and they returned to that formula in the 5th season.This is a set that, for myself, is a real keeper.  I got this as a tax refund splurge and I don't regret it.

reviewText: Many people have commented on the pristine picture and sound, and it's all true. These shows look astonishingly brilliant and vivid and crisp. It's remarkable.Having this collection to own is a joy. It is a piece of television history, one of the best programs ever. Revisiting The Twilight Zone will make you feel young again. Its wondrous writing, creativity, acting, and storytelling are still fantastic after nearly fifty years. The tales here are at times powerful, disturbing, frightening, deeply poignant, sweet and amusing, or profoundly moving.My complaint with this collection involves special features, specifically the recordings of audio interviews that Marc Scott Zicree conducted with some of the actors and writers. Granted, it is interesting to listen to these conversations, however Mr. Zicree has the distracting and annoying habit of quickly saying "Mmm hmm, mmm hmm" immediately after almost every sentence spoken by the person he questions. The actor or writer barely gets a thought spoken when Zicree chirps out yet another "Mmm hmm, mmm hmm" like he is grossly overcaffeinated or very nervous. It's ridiculous. Let the person finish a thought without interruption. I was delighted listening to actor Burgess Meredith or the great writer Richard Matheson, but their recollections and musings are often cut off by these sudden, needless interjections.But I can forgive that because this collection is amazing. (And I can live without a 'Play All' function in the dvd menu; although that would have been great. I actually expect that feature on all television dvd's. It's surprising to see it absent. Yet it's a mere trifle because these stories and characters are worth cherishing.)Finally, if you are on the fence about purchasing this collection, I would encourage you to buy it. Treat yourself to these fine TV productions. This is good stuff. This is food for the imagination.

reviewText: Put me down also as being one who previously purchased an entire Twilight Zone collection (I bought all 43 of the "themed" discs when Amazon was clearing them out at $4.99 each, I should have known something was coming to replace them, but live and learn...) only to find this superior release appear on the scene after the fact. I then went ahead and bought the first season of this definitive collection anyway to see if it was that much better and found it contained the Scott Marc Zicree book, "The Twilight Zone Companion" that I had ALSO just purchased at Amazon. Now I am double-dipping on books too!That doesn't matter though (especially since I was still able to recoup my losses by reselling the mostly unopened discs on ebay) because this collection of the entire series in the "definitive" version is restored both visually and aurally and includes extras such as interviews with writers, directors, actors and best of all, Rod Serling himself (in the form of question and answer sessions during a lecture). Plus, you get the original commercial bumpers and teaser previews from Rod about the upcoming episodes. I have to say though, I can't sit through the Zicree interviews because of the annoying habit he has of constantly interrupting the interviewee's comments with a continuous "uh-huh. huh." mantra that is every bit as tortuous to listen to as a faucet dripping. Another minor annoyance would be the sheer number of steps required to view each episode (a feature I did not like about the older DVD versions either) whereby you can't just "play all" or even "play episode" but rather go to scene selection and start on the first scene.Other than those miner quibbles, this is a fantastic value over buying the 5 Definitive seasons separately (of course, I got it for only $155 during an online sale, so your mileage may vary) but be warned it does NOT contain the TZ companion book that the season 1 definitive set contains. This did not matter to me since I already own the full size version of it.The packaging of a book-like format with plastic trays for each disc of each season saves a lot of space over buying the slimline digipak versions of each season separately, if space if a concern for you. However, it does make the set more susceptible to damage during shipping and "floaters" being damaged, so check your pack when you get it in case you need to replace anything.All in all, a suitably honorable restoration and presentation of this wonderful series that any fan will love and consider to indeed be the "definitive" edition (at least until the next one comes along.)

reviewText: If you're even 1% of the Twilight Zone fan I am, you couldn't even consider not grabbing this set, regardless of any imperfections. Now that I own them all and can see them all in order, I see that those episodes I'd believed were the earliest were actually from the second season.  So, I have no idea why the quality of those few differs so from the rest.The one inexplicable disappointment I had with this set involves the quality of the episode somewhat coincidentally named "Static."  I've seen it many times, and it never looked this bad; so, I can't understand why they didn't use a cleaner copy to digitize for this set.  Given the overall high level of quality, the problems in this episode in particular are that much more unaccountable to me.  I believe that they should have made the effort to obtain a cleaner copy to digitize to bring "Static" up to the standard of the rest of the set. reviewText: I've cobbled my Twilight Zone seasons together from different sources, buying both new and used. The first three were bought as Definitive EDITION season sets, while years 4 and 5 came from broken up Definitive COLLECTION sets. While I would rather have had all of one or the other, this does give me the opportunity to offer a side-by-side comparison of the two package designs.The most noticable difference is in size: The Definitive Editions come in boxed sets of five or six black plastic clamshell cases, each holding one disk apiece(Why they didn't offer cases that hold two disks, is probably because the show went to DVD before consolidation became the norm). The disks are  well protected, easy to remove, and a complete episode/bonus features index is located conveniently on the backside of each case.However, my season sets from The Definitive Collection are another matter. While smaller in bulk than the above-mentioned Edition sets, the disks themselves are mounted on three hard plastic "pages", one disk per side. Perhaps others know the secret, but I have personally found the disks to be extremely difficult to remove, no matter how hard I pressed on the center spindle. There were times when I even feared breaking something! Of course, this completely killed the mood I was in to watch TV. The compact design of these sets also leaves no room for episode indexes, so a separate multi-page brochure must also be provided, leaving you to have to thumb through until finding the page for the disk in question.My final complaint is leveled against the DVD release in general. While others have pointed out, quite correctly, how wonderfully clear and detailed the images are, I still noticed a liberal sprinkling of specks and other foreign matter throughout the episodes, as well as frequent vertical track lines. Sure, its easy to point out how old these prints are, but Star Trek is nearly as old, and the images of it on DVD look as if they were just filmed YESTERDAY. This is not merely luck, but rather the result of a costly, labor-intensive process which is necessary if a company is going to offer sets which are truly "digitally remastered".

reviewText: Let's face it, if you grew up in the United States from the late 1960's onward, "The Twilight Zone" was part of your childhood. Either staying up late with siblings or parents, or if you were brave enough, by yourself, catching the odd "Zone" rerun here or there on the old UHF channels, or on late night cable TV. I'm sure most of us remember our childhood impressions of first seeing "The Monsters are Due on Maple Street" or "The Invaders". Watching "Zone" as a kid was a rite of passage most of us have gone through, and something we all remember.Now, fifty years after the series first premiered the show still seems as fresh and original as when it first aired. For the most part, the stories are timeless, and while "Zone" is mostly remembered for it's shocking tales of the sci-fi and horror variety, it's almost too easy to forget about the excellent dramatic tales like "The Big Tall Wish" or "A Passage for Trumpet" from season 1 or "Nothing in the Dark" from Season 2. The series also featured a good many comedic episodes such as "Hocus-Pocus and Frisby" of "Mr. Garrity and the Graves". Basically "The Twilight Zone" offers something for everyone.Over the past year or so my wife and I have been tucking ourselves in at night by watching 1 or 2 episodes before bed. ("The Twilight Zone" is the type of show that should only be watched when the moon is out). Sure, there are a few clunkers sprinkled here or there throughout the series, but for a show lasting 5 years, with multiple writers, directors, and a revolving cast, the are surprisingly few. Last night we finished the last disk in this set, and the last original episode with "The Bewitchin' Pool". It has been a lot of fun watching these shows in order, and has become a nice nightly tradition for us. I'm going to miss Rod Serling's narration every evening.There is a plethora of extras, the shows look fantastic, the sound is phenomenal. This set was put together by true fans of the show, and it's a fitting showcase for one of television's most iconic shows.

reviewText: I've seen Blu-ray transfers that are pretty good, and some that are quite awful. Normally for films as old as these (1959 ff) I would expect the digital transfer to contain a lot of "trace elements" of its time: some film feed "bump," graininess, flecks/scratches in the film, fuzziness along the corners/margins of the picture, etc. etc. However, CBS has done a world-class service at digitizing (and therefore preserving) the original film like I have never seen before.I'm aghast how clear and smooth the picture is on these Blu-rays. Film flecks? Virtually non-existent. Bouncing frames? Nope. Grainy? Not at all. Fuziness? Never. The picture is so crisp and clear that it actually looks like a modern hi-def recording that has been filmed in black and white. And the motion during pans is smooth as silk.I'm not a videographer, so I don't know the proper terms for calling out the problems I normally see in older footage that's been digitized, but whatever the studio did for The Twilight Zone needs to be taught in film schools.Yes, this set is expensive. But your money will go a long way, as these episodes have been preserved and presented in pristine, head-spinning clarity.
summary: Videographers take note: THIS is how you do it

reviewText: Wow! Almost every episode has its own Bonus Feature(s) and then each season has it's own set of Bonus Features. This is Definitely the Definitive set of "Twilight Zone".The great thing about "The Twilight Zone", is that most of the episodes and their themes are timeless. The only one that really seems to me to be annoyingly out of date is "The Old Man in the Cave" (season 5, 11/8/63). After a nuclear war, Mr. Goldsmith helps his little community by taking their canned provisions into a cave, where "the Old Man" decides which cans are contaminated and which can be safely eaten. The Old Man is always right. Then the people discover that the Old Man is actually a computer. They are so enraged by this that they destroy the computer. That was 1963. Nowadays, people would be more likely to believe a computer than they would a live person!And the DVD set-up is great, too. The 28 DVD's are divided into 5 slipcases, one for each season. No overlapping DVD's, each DVD is securely held with only one DVD to each side - less opportunity to scratch the DVDs. You get the "Twilight Zone" pilot, plus 155 episodes plus, on the last DVD, the full episode of the PBS "American Masters" episode titled "Rod Serling Submitted For Your Approval". It originally aired December 2003.I have only one negative to say about the Complete Definitive Collection, and that is that, on each disc, there is no "play all" option. You have to select each episode from the disc's main menu. However, given that each episode has at least one bonus feature all it's own, this may be a good idea. Otherwise, you could miss all the episodes' special features.The episode-specific extras are in all shapes and sizes. For the pilot, "Where is Everybody?", you can watch the episode with the great Bernard Hermann's isolated score, or you can watch the episode with Earl Holiman's commentary track. Holiman says that that the part had first been offered to Tony Curtis, but he wanted too much money. Earl got the script, and says, "I read it during dinner that night, and the hair was standing up on the back of my neck."Other episode-specific bonus features include the full radio drama of the same episode (example: "One For the Angels"), an interview with someone involved with the episode (example: "I Sing The Body Electric" with an interview with producer Buck Houghton), a clip from another TV show (example: "Cavender Is Coming" has a 1961 skit from "The Garry Moore Show" - Serling does its Twilight Zone spoof introduction).It would take too much room to give you all the end-of-season Bonus Features, so I'll give you a taste by listing just the Season 1 extras:1. Where is Everybody?--A. Original pilot version including Rod Serling's pitch (used to sell the series to CBS)--B. Audio commentary by producer William Self--C. reviewerName: Jacques COULARDEAU "A soul doctor, so to say"
reviewText: This is the old black and white series. It is interesting, even in its totality, because of the concept that is behind the stories. It is always starting from a real situation, real characters, even when it is situated in the past, or the future. And systematically that normal and simple situation, perfectly believable in itself, is warped into something that is mind-raking, brain-storming and at times slightly frightening or bizarre. Some of these bizarre episodes are only what happens in the mind of the characters who gets deranged in a way or another, or the events themselves get accidentally stranded on some side road of logic though not entirely illogical.It is also true that many episodes are more surprising because they are the result of some absolutely illogical event, or some Extra-Sensorial-Perception that leads the character to adapting his action to something he knows though there is no objective reason he should know, no objective way he could have learned.This type of science fiction is possible on TV, provided it respects the rule of that new medium (at the time) and provided the audience plays the game. The game is that we are supposed to project ourselves into the story and the story is supposed to play on all our senses and not on our logical mind. The logical wrapping is used only to make the all-sensorial discourse work and be effective. It is one of the series of the late 1950s and early 1960s that demonstrated that McLuhan was right: a lot of close-ups on faces essentially, little brisk or fast movements, no overloading of the setting, simple and clear dialogue, and all sensorial discourse with a simple logical wrapping.The objective is not to make you think but to entertain you. It is not speaking to your mind or intelligence but to your sensorial comfort, or discomfort, response anyway.One defect which was kept all along: the intervention of the anchorman after the first opening scene to explain us how we were going to cross into the Twilight Zone. That's the sign of a lack of trust in the audience: if you don't put all the dots on all the i's, the audience won't understand. Today we would prefer moving from normal to paranormal and then to surreal and supernatural without anyone telling us about it. But that is a sign of the times: in those days producers thought that you had to tell people about that divide between reality and the twilight zone if you did not want to create a panic based on people believing what they were seeing on TV as being 100% true or maybe even 150% true.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU

reviewText: a man in his 40s. See him sitting at his computer writing yet another review for Amazon.com. Smart, educated, funny. He is the kind of man that men envy and women want to be with. There's just one thing, though, tonight this man will find out he lives in the Twilight Zone...This show was absolutely fantastic. The writing, the acting, the production value, everything about this show was/is/and will always be perfect. You couldn't make a show like this now. It has too much depth, too much insight, too much actual truth in it for the networks to handle. It seems as though television's motto today is, "Keep 'em numb, keep 'em dumb". Yeah, there are a few good shows that actually have some intelligence to them, but nothing packs a punch like the original Twilight Zone. The beauty of Serling and his collaborator's writing was that it was tight and yet sparse. They didn't spell everything out for you. They assumed you had a brain and that you were capable enough to use it. In fact, a lot of the stories that were on the "creepy side" were not about the things you didn't know, but the things you thought you did. I mean, who would've guess that To serve Man was actually a cookbook?I used to really look forward to Thanksgiving Day...no, not because of the dried out old bird with the runny gray stuff oozing out of it that my aunt insisted was turkey and stuffing, but the annual Twilight Zone marathon. Every year on the Los Angeles station, KTLA, channel 5 they had a morning till night Twilight Zone marathon with the top five being in the latter part of the marathon. No matter how many times I saw certain episodes, they still gave me the "wooly bumps". Like for instance, Terror at 20,000 feet. A young Bill Shatner sees a monster doing some rather destructive things to the wing of the airplane he is flying on. They told him it was all in his mind. They insinuated he was going crazy. They deboard the plane and there is a shot of the airplane wing with damage done to it....ooooo...I still get a little freaked out thinking about it.You want to talk about irony? Oh, the Twilight Zone delivers over and over again with "everyone's favorite", Time Enough, At Last;All Burgess Meredith wants to do is read. Nobody can understand his compulsion to want to read. Mmmm...maybe he wants to escape his nagging wife, his dimwitted boss, his small-minded fellow employees. So he goes into the bank vault on his lunch break to read his books, when he comes out, a disaster has happened...or has it?The world has been hit by a nuclear bomb and the only one remaining is Burgess Meredith. Finally, he has all the time in the world to read his books. He reaches over for one of his books and he drops his glasses and they crack. Oh, man...it was sad then and it is sad now just writing it. Irony: it's a twisted thing.This is a beautiful collection and everyone Twilight Zone fan should own it. Yeah, something "even better" will probably come out later on, production companies tend to do this to make another buck, but I am very happy with this collection. You also get a little documentary on Rod serling, himself. The guy was a genius. He passed away in 1975 and television has never been the same since.It's not that "they" can't make shows like this, anymore, it's that they won't. And as much as I am a fan of Lost, sometimes I feel that even the writers of the show don't exactly know where they are going with it..."Let me take one more hit, dude, and then I'll write this week's show.....uhhh...what show am I writing for again?"But with the Twilight Zone, you always knew you were headed for something creepy, something strange, something to bring you back into touch with the sweet, strange mysteries of life itself...Peace & Blessings

reviewText: Twilight Zone: The Complete Definitive CollectionAbsolutely magnificent!! Don't worry too much about it....I used to work at EMI(Canada), the Canadian division for the worldwide record company, and though I usually worked in the warehouse, I sometimes helped out in the factory section during rush releases. First of all, cds and dvds are not iserted into their plastic holders by machines, but rather, by actual human beings, and secondly, we would have to pull each disc in a series, up and off, of a long metal spool. When doing something like this for a huge order, (especially something as big as a 28 disc set!), it's nearly impossible not to get the odd fingerprint, smudge, scuff marks (from other discs on spools, etc.), and occasional plastic dust, on some csds and dvds. Of course the factory is clean and tidy, and workers make every effort not to touch, or fumble the discs, but you've got to expect a few slight (usually harmless) flaws in large rush-release, gigantic boxset orders! I too, had a few of these on about three of my discs, but I immediately understood. If you find the odd small scratch, or two, smudges, tiny plastic particles or whatever, just blow off any particles, then gently dab the area (on the disc), with a soft damp cloth, and dry it the same way with a dry soft cloth. Scratches and scuff marks will remain, but it should still play beautifully.Finally, regarding problems some have had with releasing the discs from the holders, I found that it was easiest when applying the most pressure to the middle holding spindle, while gently pulling the outer edges of the discs, here and there. reviewText: Like a lot of the fans, I've watched and re-watched all 156 episodes from the original 1959-64 sci-fi series "The Twilight Zone", bought the DVDs, and now the Blu-rays.  The high quality of the writing, the often-memorable photography by George T. Clemens, the signature title theme and some of the memorable scores, the wide range of genres attempted (from comedy, western, horror, to straight drama and fantasy), the trademarked surprise twist endings, and above all, the often thought-provoking themes are what enthrall all the Zone fans to this day.Many of the episodes involve some kind of tragic irony, or a cruel twist of fate at the end.  In "Time Enough At Last", Burgess Meredith is a bookworm who tries to find time to read, but to no avail.  In "The Hitchhiker", a young woman tries to escape from a stalker, only to find that...she can't escape.  "One More Pallbearer" is about a man who hides in a bomb shelter as the world ends.  In "The Silence", a man bets that he can remain completely silent for a specified period of time; he wins the bet, but still loses.Some episodes have subtle or obvious, mostly liberal, progressive themes.  "The Obsolete Man" is about an old man on trial for being obsolete in a totalitarian state.  In the fantasy episode "A Quality of Mercy", Dean Stockwell is a World War II soldier who physically turns into a Japanese and gets the enemy's point of view.  "The Encounter" tackles racism head on, and it's a rarely shown episode where a Japanese-American (George Takei) is locked in a room with a virulent bigot.  I recall at least a couple of episodes involving Adolf Hitler.  And quite a few episodes promote tolerance of various kinds.My favorite type of episodes are the ones about dreams and illusions that play tricks on the hero(ine)'s mind.  "Perchance to Dream" -- a man dare not go to sleep because the woman in his nightmare would kill him.  "The Midnight Sun" -- the Earth is moving towards the sun and the heat-stricken heroine is...seeing things.  "Shadow Play" -- this is the famous episode where Dennis Weaver has to go through the same nightmare over and over again.  "An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge" -- an Oscar-winning episode, though not made by Serling and company, about a Civil War soldier's illusion.  And, of course, the very first episode, "Where is Everybody?", where the hero finds himself in a strange place without knowing who or where he is.And I've only scratched the tip of the iceberg.  This legendary, 3-time Emmy-winning series that spans 5 glorious seasons is filled with gems that will continue to fascinate viewers for generations to come, just as it did the first time it aired.TZ has been a perennial fixture on home video.  VHS, laserdisc, and DVD galore of various "episode collections" have been released in the past.  But only TWO serious attempts at releasing the whole series have been made: The "Definitive Edition" DVDs from 2004-5, and the Blu-ray editions of 2010-11, both from Image Entertainment.Both editions offer uncut, full episodes in great-looking restored black-and-white picture.  The high-def 1080p picture on the Blu-ray is, however, stunning.  The series was shot on 35mm film, and the Blu-ray's almost pristine-looking picture shows beautiful fine grains and great details and clarity that indicate great efforts in preservation and restoration.  Both editions offer fine audio mono tracks, while the Blu-ray also offers "remastered audio" (still mono) tracks that have less noise.Season 1 of the Definitive Edition DVD does not have subtitles nor closed captioning, while Season 2-5 have closed-captioning only.  All seasons of the Blu-ray editions come with optional English subtitles shown all-caps in a large font.  All the supplements, however, have no subtitles nor closed-captioning.Supplements are quite fully-loaded on both editions, and even more so on the Blu-ray.  Almost all from the Definitive Editions were carried over to the Blu-ray, but some weren't.Bad news first.  The wonderful 90-minute documentary "Submitted For Your Approval" from 1995 was not carried over to the Blu-ray.  Neither was the 45-second clip of "The Drew Carey Show" paying homage to "Time Enough at Last".  Also gone are all five PDF files of the vintage "Gold Key" Twilight Zone color comics.  The colorized sequences in Season 4's "Miniature", used for syndication in 1984, is not on the Blu-ray (!).  Also gone is the hilarious 5-minute comedy bit that Serling did on "The Jack Benny Show" ("I'm the Mayor of this town.  They named it after me.  I'm Mr. Zone.  You can call me 'Twi'."). A PDF script of "Twenty Two" with Serling's annotation is also not included.  Also not on the Blu-ray is the 3-minute clip of the episode "It's Still a Good Life" from the 2003 Twilight Zone TV series that reunites Bill Mumy and Cloris Leachman.  Photo galleries, running 2 minutes for each season, are also gone.  ALL these pretty memorable bonuses are on the Definitive Edition DVDs only, and NOT the Blu-ray.Some great features DID get carried over to the Blu-ray, fortunately: Mike Wallace's 21-minute interview with Rod Serling in 1959; a 15-minute clip of Serling's appearance on the talk show "Tell it to Groucho"; all of Serling's audio-only lectures at Sherwood Oaks College; Serling's sales pitch to producers in Netherlands; footage from the Emmy Awards ceremonies where the series won its 3 awards; Saturday Night Live's spoof of the series; clips from two episodes of the 1980s Twilight Zone series.Then there are features where the Blu-ray offers improvement over the DVD.  The Definitive Edition DVDs come with 27 audio commentaries and 29 radio dramas, which is already a decent amount.  But the Blu-ray keeps all of them and adds a whole lot more -- to a total of 100 audio commentaries and 84 radio dramas.  One would think the extra commentaries might not bring anything more to the table, but they are actually QUITE GOOD.  They were recorded by several experts of the series, such as Marc Scott Zicree (without whose tremendous contribution, as many fans know, we probably wouldn't even be watching these discs), Gary Serani, Jim Benson, Scott Skelton, and others.  Their tracks are informative and a pleasure to listen to.  Some of Zicree's tracks seems to contain even more details than his own seminal work, "The Twilight Zone Companion Book".The radio dramas are another phenomenon created by the great love of the series.  A group called the Falcon Picture Group started producing radio plays in 2002 by adapting Twilight Zone episodes.  All 156 episodes have been adapted into radio plays that run about 40 minutes each, with expanded storylines, performed by actors like Jason Alexander, Stacey Keach, Jane Seymour, Kim Fields, etc.  As I mentioned, the Blu-ray only has 84 of them.  You can buy the rest at iTunes or at the official site TwilightZoneRadio dot com for two dollars per episode.  Or you can find your local radio stations that air them.  These are decent adaptations with writings and performances that are in the true spirit of the series that Serling would no doubt approve.The Blu-ray contains some NEW extras.  The first thing is something that seems to have gone unnoticed, but is quite important.  On the Definitive Edition DVDs, some of Serling's "next week's promo" segments are audio-only, apparently missing the video; and some segments are absent entirely.  The Blu-ray RESTORES the video of those audio-only segments, and adds those missing segments, so now all episodes have their "next week's promos", except, of course, the season finales.The Blu-ray contains NEW video interviews of Dana Dillaway from "One for the Angels", Suzanne Lloyd from "Perchance to Dream", Beverly Garland from "The Four of Us are Dying",  Joseph Ruskin from "The Man in the Bottle", H.M. Wynant of "The Howling Man", the still yummy-looking Morgan Brittany of "Valley of the Shadow", Paul Comi from "The Parallel", John Furia, Jr. from "I Dream of Genie".  These interviews were all shot in SD, and they were apparently made around 2004 for the Definitive Editions, but for some reason were not included there.  They are in the Blu-ray editions only.Another significant addition on the Blu-ray are audio interviews of Emmy-winning cinematographer George T. Clemens done by Marc Scott Zicree in the 70s.  Every season has about half-hour of interview, a total of about 3 hours.  This is fascinating stuff for those who want to know more about the show's camera work, which is not dealt with in depth anywhere else on the Blu-ray.The Blu-ray also adds a "Tales of Tomorrow" episode of "What You Need" from 1952, which serves as a comparison to the Season 1 episode of "What You Need".  It was originally a live broadcast recorded in Kinescope, so the video quality is understandably poor.Another major addition on the Blu-ray is the 1958 pre-series pilot episode "The Time Element", starring William Bendix as someone with a recurring dream.  This 1-hour episode has a nicely restored 1080p picture.  Serling had to wait until 1959 for the series to be picked up by the network.Season 3 episode "Cavender is Coming" originally had an ill-advised laugh track that was later removed in subsequent broadcasts.  This track is included only on the Blu-ray.Regarding packaging, if you buy the individual seasons of the Definitive Edition DVDs, each disc is put in an individual slim case.  But in the complete Season 1-5 Definitive Edition DVDs, discs of each season are cramped inside one case, with some disc-stacking that requires you to take out one disc in order to get to another.  The Blu-rays for the individual seasons and complete series also have each season's discs cramped inside one case, but each disc can be accessed without affecting other discs.
summary: Review of 2004-05 Definitive Edition DVDs and 2010-11 Blu-ray editions

reviewText: I'm a big fan of The Twilight Zone and shows in a similar vein likeThe Outer Limits,Night Gallery, andThe Ray Bradbury Theater. My wife loves it as well so I purchased this collection as a birthday gift for her. The digital remastering is excellent and the image and sound quality of (most of) the shows is better than I ever remember it looking/sounding when they aired on TV. It's wonderful to have all 156 episodes in one collection, as well as all of the plethora of extra goodies that accompany almost every episode. Discovering episodes I've never seen is quite a thrill too.I might have thought twice about buying this for the list price, but I was able to get it as a Gold Box deal for under a hundred dollar mark so I'm quite pleased. That works out to about 60 and episode! I don't see how the quality of a program recorded so long ago could be any better on Blu-ray, so the DVD set is perfect. The only reason I'd want the Blue-ray edition is that it is supposed to include the rare teleplay pilot episode, the "Time Element" in the season one extras.My 6 year old daughter and 10 year old son have come to enjoy it too, so we watch it together as a family activity. The kids have even taking to calling our eclectically decorated home the "Mr. Bevis" house, hah! The plot twists and concepts presented in Mr. Serling's series are as gripping and innovative today as they were in 1959 and the 60s. The scripts are not dumbed down like so many of today's sitcoms, and actually make one think. The plethora of great actors that starred in the various stories is yet another plus.Are there any negatives? A few, but nothing that detracts from my family's enjoyment of this set. A smattering of episodes have an odd video quality that looks as though they were plays filmed live with a handheld camera. I've seen a similar effect on old BBC shows. They often have dark halos around high contrast portions of the recording. The DVDs are a little difficult to remove from the boxes and I fear that I might break one in the process--though I never have. The set also lacks any closed captioning (season one only) or subtitles, and you have to click through each single episode rather than having a "play all" feature, which would have been a nice option.When on sale, The Twilight Zone: The Complete Definitive Collection DVD is a spectacular deal and a must have for fans of the original series. As the great man once said, "Imagination... its limits are only those of the mind itself." Get this set and lose yourself for a while... in the Twilight Zone.~ Kort

reviewText: One of my minor goals in life has been to never pay for postage with my orders from Amazon.  Consequently on my Wish List I always have some paperbacks or DVDs on sale that I can use to get to the magic mark for free shipping.  One of the things I have been using to make up the differences had been volumes of "The Twilight Zone," and I was just up to double-figures when I looked over what the deal was with "The Twilight Zone: The Complete Definitive Collection."  Even given the fact that I have not had a math course since I was a freshman in high school, I figured out that the price of these 28-disc set would be considerably less than in would cost me to get all of those other volumes.  Then I paid attention to the fine print and discovered that with these DVDs there were bonus features the likes of which you would not expect to see for a black & white television series that went off the air in 1964.To give you an idea of what this means, here is what you get for bonus features just on Disc One of Season 1 of "The Twilight Zone": For "Where Is Everybody?" there is audio commentary by actor Earl Holliman and an isolated score by Bernard Herman; "One for the Angels" has "The Twilight Zone" Radio Drama starring Ed Begley, Jr.; "Mr. Denton on Doomsday" has audio commentary by actor Martin Landau; "The Sixteen Millimeter Shrine" has an isolated score by Franz Waxman; "Walking Distance" has part of a Rod Serling lecture given at Sherwood Oaks College in 1975 and another isolated score by Hermann; "Escape Clause" is a rare episode without a bonus feature; and "The Lonely" has another Hermann score.Now, I can care less about the isolated scores, but the rest of the extras are great.  You really get a sense for how self-deprecating Serling was as he dismantles his episodes for his students.  The radio dramas feature such recognizable voices as those of Jane Seymour, Daniel J. Travanti, Jason Alexander, Blair Underwood, Morgan Brittany, and John Ratzenberger (Stacy Keach handles the narration duties).  I had seen the CDs for those episodes before and would never think of picking them up, so having them here is a nice little treat.  There are also intereviews by Marc Scott Zicree, author ofThe Twilight Zone Companion," with the likes of Richard Matheson, Earl Hamner, George Clayton Johnson, Brugess Meredith, Anne Francis, Maxine Stuart, Richard L. Bare, Buck Houghton, and Douglas Heyes.  So you can see there is a mix of writers, actors, and directors to be found.The list of those providing commentary tracks includes Bill Mumy (on ALL of his "Zone" episodes), Cliff Robertson, Don Rickles, Donna Douglas, Dennis Weaver, Martin Milner, Jonathan Winters, William Windom, Mariette Hartley, Leonard Nimoy, and Mickey Rooney.  These are mostly memories about making the shows and how many of them still hear from fans about what they did on the "Zone" way back when.  Elsewhere you will find such treats as a clip from "The Drew Carey Show" relevant to the classic "Time Enough at Last" and the infamous "Saturday Night Live" take-off on "The Twilight Zone," a complete script with Rod Serling's handwritten notes for "Twenty Two," Serling hosting an episode of the game show "Liars Club" (with Betty White) and the proverbial much, much more topped off by "Rod Serling: Submitted for Your Appproval," a American Masters biography of the man himself.My assumption here is that nobody needs to be sold on "The Twilight Zone" itself.  Yes, there are some lame episodes, but there are more classic "Zones" that more than balance things out.  If you have read Zicree's book a lot of what you hear in the interviews will be old news, but that is not a significant flaw.  I would have loved to have had William Shatner do a commentary track for "Nick of Time" (which I prefer to his better known appearance in "Nightmare at 20,000 Feet"), but for such disappointments there are wonderful surprised (e.g., June Foray doing audio commentary and a video interview for "Living Doll").  I have been watching an episode of the "Zone" each night after the evening news (and before network prime time began (this was in the old days when there was not a writers strike and there were new episodes of dramatic programming readily available).  The biggest surprise has been how many of these episodes I have never seen before of the half-hour episodes (I knew going in that I had only seen a handful of the hour-long ones from Season 4).  This is the first time I have spent triple digits for a television series and it took watching just that first disc to convince me I had spent my money wisely.
summary: Time enough at last for the complete collection of "The Twilight Zone"

reviewText: A master synthesizer, Rod Serling took the irony of Alfred Hitchcock Presents, the future looking elements of Science Fiction Theatre, and supernatural themes of One Step Beyond, combined them with a megadose of his imagination and produced the Twilight Zone. He wrote the bulk of the 1959 to 1964 show's 156 episodes. Other talented writers included Ray Bradbury, Earl Hamner Jr., Richard Matheson, and Charles Beaumont.A parade of future television and cinema stars appeared in the anthology. Even the unknown actors who never achieved such success contributed believable performances to each show. Perhaps that is what made it stand out from other attempts at fantasy, horror, and sci-fi that have come and gone over the years -- the plots were somehow rendered believable, whether set in the past, present, or future; on planet Earth, an asteroid, or distant planet; presented with humor, longing, or pathos.In the ultimate irony, Serling sold the package of episodes to CBS, unaware of the continued syndication showing of the show up to this day, 50 years after the show was cancelled.

reviewText: I had grown up watching The Twilight Zone. I recall the commercials for its first season airing on TV with all the hoopla about the coming decade (the 60's)--most of all I recall the omnipresent Mr. Serling standing off center (camera pan left or right), with a cigarette dangling from his first two fingers as he narrates a brief intro, promo, or closing. I watched many of the reruns from time to time on the Sci-Fi (sorry, can't get into the lame syfy moniker) channel. Problem was, you always missed some of the ones you remembered the best. I know the one with Keenan Wynn that I thought was called "The Pitch" (actually it was "One for the Angels") was as clear in my memory as if I were a nine year old watching it air for the first time, back in my old homestead. Yet I never got to see it again and was delighted that it was among the first in season 1 of this set (actually it was the SECOND TZ episode to air). The Twilight Zone was one of those very special shows that left an indelible mark on your memory. I was an imaginative child to begin with, and sci-fi/fantasy were among my favorite genre. This made Twilight Zone an absolute "must" every Friday night! What I especially like is that you have them ALL!  How can any TZ fan not be impressed with that?  And wonder of wonders, the specials are incredible!1.) Each disc has a sub menu for each episode (usually the scene menu) which includes Mr. Serling's promo for the next week's show AND a link to "specials" which run the gamut from isolated scores, where you can watch in a muted episode and hear the haunting score behind it. The imagination runs WILD.2.) Among the specials, you also get interviews with many of the stars who were featured on the episodes, including Burgess Meredith discussing "Time Enough At Last", while the episode plays in the background. The list of stars, writers, producers, is very impressive and too lengthy to list here--suffice it to say, you'll love hearing their own views of the shows they were a part of. Even Mr. Serling graces us with lectures he gives to students with his unique self-deprecating humor while looking back at special episodes.3.) The old CBS logo appears after each show, and you get promos from other shows like Danny Thomas and Wanted Dead or Alive-- even an occassional PSA about things like "take your family to church or synagogue this week" (imagine THAT in today's PC world!) there are others--but THAT one struck me as special-- takes you right back to those better times!For me, this is a welcome retreat back to a better time. Yes, I know we need to live in the present, and concern ourselves with the future--nobody better, and I do that; but once or twice a week, I cherish the opportunity to put in one of these discs and relive a time in my life when things were just less chaotic, and more filled with childlike fancy. Perhaps I'm a tad like the actress who, watching her old films wished to retreat back to her glory days as a star of celluloid (so many of the TZ episodes focused on the desire to recapture the past; remembere "Kick the Can"? --perhaps one day my own children will come into my house and see a rerun of "Walking Distance" and see me playing the role of Martin, walking back into the time of his childhood. Anyone who knows about the episode "Next Stop Willoughby" will understand why I'm not quite ready for THAT one!  Bottom line, it's a GREAT collection, with GREAT specials you'll LOVE if you are a real TZ fan, and that I am!The only drawback, if one could call it that, was the packaging. The discs slide open inside a book-like package and sit on plastic spools in dual-stacks offset somewhat. This makes for an awkward effort to dislodge the discs, some of which are a bit loose--others of which are very tight, and on one particular instance I was frightfully worried I might break DVD which resisted my every effort to dislodge it. If I ever have another episode like that, I'll just transfer them into a set of easy access DVD packages--problem solved, and the money saved over buying them in the season-by-season packages is still astounding. You can NOT do better than this set if you love the Twilight Zone, and want to learn more about those wonderful episodes imprinted permanently in your memory! Quite frankly, one of the two or three BEST TV series--EVER! -- At a price you won't beat... ANYWHERE!
summary: A MUST HAVE for any true TZ fan!

He went on to explain that the two need not be mutually exclusive.  Rod Serling proved beyond a shadow of a doubt that "The Twilight Zone" was - and remains - very popular, BECAUSE of the high quality of the writing, acting, and production. reviewText: O-K, we all know what an outstanding show the Twilight Zone ("TZ") was; and from other reviewers comments, we should all know that the quality of this set is also outstanding...so I'll just make a few comments about the extras included in this set:Some have commented that the Marc Zicree interviews are worthless and annoying. Actually, I have found them to be the best of the extras. Zicree does come off sounding like a goofy teenager (He was probably in his early 20's when these interviews were recorded in '78)- but that is actually rather refreshing in these days of sound-alike cliched polished TV personalities! Rather than putting on a phoney front, Zicree was simply acting natural. Zicrees knowledge of the show is amazing, and shows in the questions that he asks. Zicree actually manages to save what otherwise might be rather dull interviews...as many of the people from the show that he interviews seem to have a rather limited memory, or just don't seem to think as highly of the TZ as we the fans do- and Zicree helps refresh their memory and asks some very good questions, which only someone with an exceptional knowledge of the TZ could do. (After witnessing this, I think I will now buy his book about TZ!)Some of the commentors (e.g. Don Rickles, Mickey Rooney) either have nothing to say, or seem totally disinterested- so don't expect every "extra" to be a gem.It was great seeing an episode of Serlings game show The Liars Club. (Not the greatest show...but it is a treat to be able to see it). The vintage commercials and intros and extros are really wonderful, and help in keeping with the nostalgic mood that watching this set puts one in.The PBS Serling bio/documentary is great! I don't understand the purpose of them having isolated scores for many of the eps (If anyone knows, please comment!); In my opinion, the PDF format comic books are a total waste (Who the hell wants to read acomic book when you can watch the real eps??!!) and the radio dramas...sheesh! Gimme a break! Who wants to listen to modern radio dramas? It's like watching a remake of a TZ ep (only worse!)...All in all, I have to say, that this is one of the best collections of extras I've seen. There is lots of stuff..and much of it is good- it is not just filler- like is the case with many other shows. Generally, I could care less about extras...as they are usually cheesey, and just added to try and boost sales and so the studios can boast that their sets contain them....but in the case of the TZ...the extras truly enhance ones viewing experience.The packaging is nice looking and seems as sturdy as any other DVD set. The halographic effects are nice on the box and cases. The one thing that was unnerving, was that it is rather hard to get the discs out of their cases- it seems like one must exert some force...and I'm always scared that I am going to break the DVDs in removing them....but I'm getting used to it.All in all, this set is a wonderful bargain for the $170 it cost! To have every TZ ep in crystal-clear quality, is just priceless! This set is worth every penny, and is a must have for any fan of the show. In my opinion, this set sets the standard for quality that all other DVD releases should strive to emmulate.

reviewText: ...or into the Zone with Rod,...however you look into it `The Twilight Zone' is sheer masterpiece in TV production...thus what does one have to say about a show that hasn't been said before?Well, the only solution in my mind is to give you a personal view of my experience after watching this series...so here it goes..."There is a fifth dimension, beyond that which is known to man. It is a dimension as vast as space and as timeless as infinity. A plane of existence your soul interprets within the psyche of the mind. It is the middle ground between light and shadow, between science and superstition, and it lies between the pit of man's fears and the summit of his knowledge. A reality of unknown origins that is a testament to the birth of your very nature of being. This is the dimension of imagination; a dimension that tests the boundaries to its limits and beyond.  It is an area which we call the Twilight Zone."This series at the time of production was the most ambitious and unique concept that television had shown to its TV audience. It was 1959, and something new and exciting was going to hit the airwaves...it was `The Twilight Zone' hosted by Rod Serling, the most successful writer of his generation. In Serling's career, `The Twilight Zone' was to be the pinnacle of his success in television and through it Rod Serling gained unparalleled respect for genius. No other show during or since has `The Twilight Zone' an equal-and that includes today's standards.Three other shows that could be considered contemporary companions to `The Twilight Zone' are `Science Fiction Theatre', `One Step Beyond', which is an excellent series and `The Outer Limits', which I have heard, to be a poor imitation, but as I have not seen this show, I cannot comment officially.`The Twilight Zone' is many things to many people...for Rod Serling, it was his brainchild...his visual conception of his sub-conscience and inner being, his experience, his deep and inner thoughts, his fears, his musings, his successes, his failures, his sense of right and wrong, his inner longing for the unknown truths and falsehoods, that plague the deepest, darkest recesses of the one's mind. To gain access into a world where very shade, very crack in a wall, very smell of the air, very sound of unknown creation, would tell a story; and bring you into a reality that for the most part was not the reality you sought, but an actuality of realism given to the whims of your darkest fears and imagination that could border between insanity and a coherent, logical situation.It can be said to understand Rod Serling is to understand `The Twilight Zone', and to try to understand `The Twilight Zone' was to understand Rod Serling. This show has many levels, and trying to interpret and comprehend one level, would only lead you to another and another and another. The deeper you went, the deeper you would drown in a sea of blackness that no shadow could escape. A journey into one's inner psyche to gain just a foothold of Rod's awareness, was a journey in itself, fought with your innermost private, personal, and intimate secrets, that can laugh in the face of your inner soul, screaming to be heard, trapped in a cage of individual crimes against the core of your essence, wanting to escape-but never to be freed.Peeling back layer after layer, only compounds to the illusion of delusion and disillusion, disenchanting your sanity, to dishearten your very senses, that grants you just a figment of your imagination, giving a false impression, a misapprehension...a chimera of your former self in a neo-reality.A reality created by Rod Serling who dared to be...different...not only to himself, but to others also...to show the world that inside us all was an unknown intellect of confused bewilderment, that could and can mystify and perplex, a puzzle to be solved in a state of confusion, that infects your very perceptions of time and space to dimensions beyond mere thought and understanding. To go beyond the mirror and look inside yourself to find the beast within or the child full of innocence, wanting just to be left alone to play.Rod Serling through `The Twilight Zone' became an enigmatic figure, the man, the myth, the master,  a mysterious Mephistopheles, to question man's mind in the fire's of taboo, in a quest, in the forbidden, prohibited, inviolable world that man has conjured up to make peace within himself to justify his corruptible cravings, and say `I am right'.But through it all we get a glimpse...a glance of ourselves, where we too could face an unknown, unexplained situation. `The Twilight Zone' prepares us to face the un-reality of life...and death, that may befall us. We must condition our perceptions and ideas of what is, to what may...a happening...an event...an occurrence...to experience a journey of genesis, and begin again...as you enter...into a world...of  the unforseen...the stage is ready...the scene is ready...but are you?"Lights-camera-action!...welcome to...The Twilight Zone""You're travelling through another dimension, a dimension not only of sight and sound but of mind; it will take you on a journey, a journey into the forbidden world beyond your reach. The road less travelled by some, but by many, who experience the other side of reality-a pseudo imitation that borders on your insanity. A journey into a wondrous land whose boundaries are that of imagination, unparalleled beyond your wildest dreams...watch out! That's the signpost up ahead-your next stop, the Twilight Zone."Within this series there were some great episodes, and as I can't review them all...I  have picked out only some of my favourites, naturally any `Twilight Zone' fan will have their own favourite and or special episodes they like.`WHERE IS EVERYBODY?' - (Pilot Episode) - Season 1/01 - Televised on 2/10/1959.Mike Ferris finds himself wandering through a ghost town and struggles to discover his identity and where he is.Personal Comment:1] This is a great first episode to start `The Twilight Zone' with; and from what I have heard, (critically) is the best episode of the entire series (perhaps a representation of it-more likely). For two thirds of the story Earl Holliman who plays Mike Ferris holds us (the viewer) in the palm our his hand , as we too want to know where are all the people and Earl is very believable in his roll-this is a mark of a talented actor.2] Although this was the pilot of the `Twilight Zone'; many consider `The Time Element' - A time travel adventure about a man who travels back to Honolulu in 1941 and unsuccessfully tries to warn everyone about the impending attack on Pearl Harbor -  which was eventually aired as an episode of `Desilu Playhouse' in 1958; as the true pilot of `The Twilight Zone' when Serling used this story to ineffectively pitch for his show.3] Watch the scene in a soda shop after Mike is talking to himself he idly spins racks filled with paperback books until he comes to an already spinning rack filled from top to bottom with the same book - "The Last Man on Earth, Feb. 1959", an ironical touch by Serling.4] This episode has shades of the movies `The Last Man  on Earth', `The Omega Man' & `I Am Legend'.4] Also of note is actor James Gregory as a General, in the closing stages of the episode.`AND WHEN THE SKY WAS OPENED' - Season 1/11 - Televised on 11/12/1959.The crew - Col. Clegg Forbes (Rod Taylor), Col. Ed Harrington (Charles Aidman) and Major William Gart (Jim Hutton) of an experimental spaceship - X-20 DynaSoar, begin disappearing one by one after returning to Earth from space.Personal Comment:1] What happens when you are not suppose to return from a mission? Well with the shades of the movie `Capricorn One'- instead of the establishment trying to get rid of you; you begin to disappear. And it is done so well, that no one has any knowledge of those who vanished.2] Rod Taylor is convincing or trying to be, when his friend Ed first goes into limbo; then tries to convince Will. When Clegg vanishes, Will begins to believe Clegg, but he too will go where no man has gone before (Sorry, I had to put that in-I couldn't help it).3] As the spaceship's name suggests `DynoSoar' - Dinosaur, our spacemen become extinct.`PEOPLE ARE ALIKE ALL OVER' - Season 1/25 - Televised on 25/03/1960.On a mission to Mars, an astronaut Sam Conrad (Roddy McDowall) finds out that the Martians are the same as humans in many ways. When he realises what they have in store for him-for the rest of his naturally life.Personal Comment:1] It seems the Martians have a sense of humour, or they believe Man to be an inferior species, to be displayed for their amusement; or they have both. On a deeper level when you visit the zoo next time, try to empathise with the creatures you laugh and poke a stick at. Because one day you too will feel the iron bars that cage you-in one sense we are already in a zoo-called... Society.2] I believe that this was Roddy's return to the screen after spending the 1950's in the theatre. He is a great actor, and will be sorely missed.3] It's mockingly ironic that Roddy is portrayed as a caged animal like a monkey... this of course will give him experience when he does the `Planet of the Apes' films.4] Also of note is actress Susan Oliver as Teenya, who feels sorry for Sam-as she knows what's in store for him. Perhaps...one day Teenya might be able to convince her fellow Martians to let Sam go-but I doubt it.`THE EYE OF THE BEHOLDER' - Season 2/06 - Televised on 11/11/1960.Janet Tyler a disfigured woman both played by Maxine Stuart, with bandages on, then Donna Douglas, with bandages off,  undergoes plastic surgery on her face in order to look more like everyone else, but the surgery fails.Personal Comment:1] This is a brilliant, unusual and the most unique episode, as we don't see the faces of any doctors or nurses until the very end. Then we see why their faces were hidden from the viewer via dark shadows, technically excellent camera work and direction.2] Obviously we also experience, `discrimination' on a deeper level, where being different...could cost you...even your life...as we have seen in our society. It's nice to know that prejudice is still alive and well in our world (sick).`THE SILENCE' - Season 2/25 - Televised on 28/04/1961.Colonel Archie Taylor, (Franchot Tone), has difficulty enjoying his men's club because of the constant chatter of fellow member Jamie Tennyson (Liam Sullivan). Just as irritating is the content, which usually concludes with a transparent attempt to curry investors. Thus the Colonel makes a bet with Jamie Tennyson,  that he can go without speaking for a year.Personal Comment:1] I like actor Liam Sullivan in this episode, nicely played, and very talented.2] This story just goes to show how far we would go to win a $500,000 bet to get out of debt; and the character Jamie proves it to the extreme, as revealed at the end of the episode. The sad thing is the damage is permanent and Jamie is still in need of money.3] Also of special note is actor Jonathan Harris as George Alfred, nice to see him before his `Lost in Space' success.`SHADOW PLAY' - Season 2/26 - Televised on 05/05/1961.A man convicted of murder, Adam Grant (Dennis Weaver), tries to convince those about to execute him that the world all around them is just his recurring nightmare. The story opens with the jury finding Grant guilty of murder. He laughs uncontrollably and then rants that he refuses to die again. He claims that the district attorney (Harry Townes), and the lawyers are all people he has known in his past who are playing parts in his dream.Personal Comment:1] Now this is a twilight zone nightmare. You are reliving the same experience over and over again, wanting to get out; the only solution is trying to convince someone to break the sequence of events, so you can wake up. Dennis Weaver's performance is excellent here as a man trapped in his own nightmare knowing full well the outcome. 2] This may be a mute point, but I would like to know how Adam Grant got his nightmare?, perhaps this episode should have been a 2-parter, with the first showing us how it all began-that would be nice.`TWO' - Season 3/01 - Televised on 15/09/1961.A man (no name given) played by Charles Bronson and a woman (no name given) played by Elizabeth Montgomery, are survivors from opposite armies of an apocalyptic world war, who confront each other in a deserted, war-ravaged town.Personal Comment:1] What we have here is a visual setting/environment of the after effects of WWIII, between America and USSR-it's pretty obvious. This scenario tells us that war in the extreme is futile, a conflict that destroys both sides and neither is victorious. It also tells us on a sub-conscience level the tensions of the Cold War being played out during the period between America and USSR-that's pretty obvious also. But when all is said and done, there is always hope for humanity, when the two sides realise that peace is the only way forward.2] With the above you need to read between the lines as we watch Charles Bronson (representing America) and Elizabeth Montgomery (representing USSR), play out their roles to confirm the realities of the time and to some extent...the future as well...it is a warning to us all...even today.`TO SERVE MAN' - Season 3/24 - Televised on 02/03/1962.A technologically superior alien race arrives on Earth with a promise to serve mankind.Personal Comment:1] If there is one episode that has become a penultimate classic of `The Twilight Zone', then `To Serve Man' is the one. Rod Serling knew how to deliver the goods on a platter-so to speak, when he wrote this story.2] The Kanamits, a race of nine-foot-tall aliens, land on Earth. One of them played by Richard Kiel (who will later be successfully known as Jaws in two James Bond films), addresses the United Nations, vowing that his race's motive in coming to Earth is solely to be helpful to humanity.3] The episode is based on the short story "To Serve Man", written by Damon Knight. The title is a play on the verb serve, which has a dual meaning of "to assist" and "to provide as a meal." The episode is one of the few instances in the series wherein the actor (in this instance played by Lloyd Bochner as Chambers) breaks the fourth wall and addresses the viewing audience at the episode's end.4] Question: Why did the Kanamit leave his book `To Serve Man' at the UN after his meeting with its members? Surely this was no mistake-or was it? (I mean, does being intelligent mean being forgetful?) If it wasn't for the book, Patty played by Susan Cummings, would not have completely deciphered the alien's language to find its true meaning (a cookbook) within the contents of the story.5] Question: Now that the book has been deciphered, what will man do about the Kanamits? (Cannibals).6] This episode raises more questions than answers about man's ability to trust another race-especially his own, if we as a society can't seem to trust another country, how can  we trust so easily another foreign power-as it were?`NO TIME LIKE THE PAST' - Season 4/10 - Televised on 07/03/1963.Paul Driscoll (Dana Andrews) travels back in time and tries to change important historical events.Personal Comment:1] What we have here a man disillusioned with life and the society he lives in. He sees with his own clarity the ugliness of the 20th century, and the events he believes shaped and formed the present state of human existence. Paul Driscoll so hates the current world that he uses a time machine to change key events in Man's history, so the world can be a better place...in the end he ultimately fails because of unforseen circumstances that make past history unchangeable. Even to the point when Paul Driscoll himself was the cause of a fire of a schoolhouse in 1881 Homeville. Does this mean that in the scheme of things that history knew of Paul Driscoll's involvement and that history knew that Paul Driscoll was going back in time, even before Paul Driscoll knew about it himself?2] We as human beings always dream of the better life, a better way of living; we think of the past as a dream of better yesterday's, when and where life was `simple'. This is usually the child within us thinking out loud, not knowing tomorrow, but us we grow older, we begin to understand our environment and it's realities. And we say to ourselves `I don't like what I see and what I have become apart of; I am trapped in a world/society that I need to escape from'. But the reality is, we cannot escape and only death seems the only way out...for some.3] The lesson we learn here is...better your own life as best you can, and live your life the best you can...remember...it is not the end of your life that matters...but the journey through it...that determines how you live your life for the better.`THE PARALLEL' - Season 4/11 - Televised on 14/03/1963.Astronaut Robert Gaines (Steve Forrest) blacks out while orbiting the earth. Suddenly, his communication systems stop functioning and he blacks out, waking up on Earth with no memory of his return. But realizing he is in a  parallel universe.Personal Comment:1] I like this story and I like Steve Forrest, who is Dana Andrews younger brother-just in case you didn't know. This episode has shades of the movie `Journey to the Far Side of the Sun' - an excellent film.2] I do believe in other universes, the universe we are currently in is just a bubble...and there are countless bubbles out there. All universes are sightly different in appearance...in this universe you may have a sister...in another universe you do not, and so it goes. All these differences make up the fabric of time and space...some known and unknown. But they are all connected by interstellar threads known as...Black Holes. Yes, I know scientists state that nothing can survive in a Black Hole and that Black Holes are not doorways to other universes...but they can't physically prove it...because the mysteries of the universe are vast and unknown. We as a species have yet to leave our Solar System, let alone colonise the Moon and or Mars...we have a long way to go...before we understand anything at all.3] Other actors of note in this episode are Jacqueline Scott as Helen Gaines, Frank Aletter as Colonel Connacher, and Paul Comi as The Psychiatrist, all fine performances.`PROBE 7, OVER AND OUT' - Season 5/09 - Televised on 29/11/1963.Astronaut Adam Cook (Richard Basehart) crash lands on a strange planet with gravity and atmospheric conditions similar to those on his home world. Most of his equipment is put out of commission by the crash and he cannot repair it due to a broken arm and lack of resources, so he is stranded.Personal Comment:1] One does not get the biblical connection until the second half of the episode when Adam Cook befriends a woman by the name of Eve Norda (Antoinette Bower), who is also stranded on the planet...which turns out to be the planet Earth...that's right our planet Earth, which means we came from an alien race and the Neanderthals were the true humans of the planet...now extinct.2] With shades of Erich von Daniken's theory that man came from the stars this is pretty close to home...it's like saying what came first, the chicken or the egg. Religious fanatics will have a field day, stating holy blasphemy against the word of God. But luckily for Rod Serling...he won't be burned at the stake.3] One thing is true though is that we are made of star stuff as Carl Sagan once said.4] Another question arises...if Man was created by God...and Man evolved from the ape...then there are two species of Man living on this planet...thus which species do you belong too? Be careful now, wars have known to be started in this way.`THE LONG MORROW' - Season 5/15 - Televised on 10/01/1964.Commander Douglas Stansfield (Robert Lansing) an astronaut in the year 1987, is sent to a planetary system 141 light-years from Earth. The trip will take 20 years each way. To save him the ordeal of forty years of loneliness, he is to be placed in (newly-developed) suspended animation. Before leaving, he meets and becomes enchanted by his young colleague, Sandra Horn (Mariette Hartley). However, Horn would be 40 years older and Stansfield would still be young because of the suspended animation. Stansfield goes on his mission and 40 years later he returns (tragically, the job he was sent to do was already completed, using technology developed after he left). He thus returns a forgotten pioneer.Personal Comment:1] I consider this a most tragic and heartbreaking story, where love is both the winner and the loser in this tale. It just proves to us all that love is a strength beyond any power Man could create to supersede it. This is one story that definitely has no happy ending.2] Having said the above, there are a couple of things wrong with this story in any case - One: If Sandra Horn was going to put herself in suspended animation, knowing that Douglas Stansfield was also going to do the same-mission wise...why didn't she tell him, even before he left? Two: After six months, Stansfield cancelled his hibernation, so he could grow old by 40 years, how did he do this? Assuming the  suspended animation was controlled via computer to wake him at his destination? Three: With being in suspended animation, there would be no call to have an extensive supply of food-perhaps 2 months at the most-maybe not even that (if there was ever room). So how could Stansfield survive for 40 years? Four: That being said, how could a man live alone on a ship for so long...you would go mad...I certainly would. Five: If the technology was developed 20 years later to find out the information of the planetary system after Stansfield left, why didn't Mission Control program the ship to come back? Certainly via the story, communications failed 12 hours after launch, but I assume Mission Control has tracking ability to contact the ship to program it. Six: Thus if via the story there was sporadic contact-communication wise during the 40 year mission, surely one communiqué would have gotten through. Seven: Did Stansfield know of the Communication malfunction, when he came out of suspended animation? If he did could he have fixed it or perhaps he wasn't qualified-not his field.`AN OCCURRENCE AT OWL CREEK BRIDGE' - Season 5/22 - Televised on 28/02/1964.Peyton Farquhar, (Roger Jacquet) a Civil War civilian prisoner and spy, is about to be hanged from Owl Creek Bridge. As he is dropped, the rope breaks and he swims away, the soldier's bullets missing him. Avoiding capture, he arrives at his home and sees his wife (Anne Cornaly) and child. He runs toward his wife and she toward him. Just as they are about to fall into each other's arms, the scene cuts back to Farquhar being dropped from the platform and hanged on the bridge. The entire escape was a dream or hallucination that he experienced in the seconds before his death.Personal Comment:1] I consider this episode the most distinctive and exceptionally brilliantly directed by Robert Enrico; there is hardly any dialog in this story. So one could watch it as a silent film and still understand what's going on. This episode is so different to other `Twilight Zone' outings, that it stands out, possible because it was filmed in France and also by its individual technique in the way it was filmed  and directed by Robert Enrico.2] The episode's introduction is notable for Rod Serling breaking the fourth wall even more than usual, as he explains how the film was shot overseas in France and later picked up to air as part of `The Twilight Zone' series.3] With this episode we are treated to perhaps another version in interpretation of the `Twilight Zone' seem from director Robert Enrico's point of view. I get the feeling that this episode was a test to see how it would take to the American audience...if successful, perhaps a 6th season of `The Twilight Zone' may have had more overseas outings/episodes...but of course we will never know.4] `An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge', won first prize for `Best Short Subject' at the 1962 Cannes Film Festival and won the 1963 Academy Award for `Live Action Short Film'. Thus is a very worthy addition to the series as a whole."There is a dimension-a dimension that is beyond the boundaries of the understanding of man and his perceptions of mind, body and soul. It is the day that turns into the night, where oceans of emotion sway to and fro with the cosmic ebb and tide of space and time. You are a pawn in a universal chess game that plays out your life...towards the end game...towards the Twilight Zone"Okay...let's look at the `Shock' DVD collection Special Features that I have, which may be different to one that is shown here-all episodes are in B/W and have been digitally remastered; it's a 28 disc set: Season 1 has 6 disc's, Season 2 has 5 disc's, Season 3 has 5 disc's, Season 4 has 6 disc's and Season 5 has 6 disc's.Season 1 Special Features:- Audio commentaries by Earl Holliman, Martin Landau, Rod Taylor, Martin Milner, Kevin McCarthy, Ted Post & William Self.- Vintage audio recollections with Burgess Meredith, Douglas Heyes, Richard L. Bare, Buck Houghton, Anne Francis & Richard Matheson.- Rod Serling audio lectures from Sherwood Oaks College.- Isolated Music Scores featuring the legendary Bernard Herrmann, Jerry Goldsmith and more.- Original unaired pilot version of "Where is Everybody?" with Rod Serling's Network pitch and more.Season 2 Special Features:- Audio commentaries by Doona Douglas, Don Rickles, William Idelson, Bill Mumy, Cliff Robertson, Dennis Weaver & Shelley Berman.- Vintage audio recollections with Buzz Kulik, Douglas Heyes, Maxine Stuart, George Clayton Johnson, Robert Serling & Elliot Silverstein.- Isolated Music Scores featuring the legendary Bernard Herrmann, Jerry Goldsmith, Fred Steiner and more.- Rod Serling promos for "Next Week's" Show.Rare Serling appearances: The Mike Wallace Interview, TellIt to Groucho & The Jack Benny Show.Season 3 Special Features:- Audio commentaries by Bill Mumy, Lois Nettleton, William Windom, Leonard Nimoy, Robert Cornthwaite & Cliff Robertson.- Vintage audio recollections with Vintage Marc Scott Zicree.- Audio interviews with Buzz Kulik, Buck Houghton, Richard L. Bare, Lamont Johnson, Earl Hammer, Jnr. & William F. Nolan.- Isolated Music Scores featuring the legendary Van Cleave, Bernard Herrmann, Fred Steiner, Nathan Scott and more.- Rod Serling promos for "Next Week's" Show.- Twilight Zone comic Book - PDFSeason 4 Special Features:- Rod Serling promos for "Next Week's" Show.- The famous writers school promo spot with Rod Serling.- Photo galleries & Twilight Zone comic Book - PDF.Season 5 Special Features:- Commentaries and interviews featuring Mickey Rooney, Martin Landau, Michael Constantine, Bill Mumy, Carolyn Kearney, Mariette Hartley & Earl Hammer, Jnr.- American Masters: "Submitted For Your Approval" - A 90 minute documentary on the life of Rod Serling.Well I think that's about it for this review, so I hope you enjoyed my contribution to this cult classic series...I thoroughly enjoyed my `Twilight' experience in watching this show; and with today's standard outings on TV, it's such a refreshing change to watch quality TV at it's best. If you haven't seen `The Twilight Zone' yet, then I suggest you take the trip into the unknown and experience the world created by Rod Serling and his vision of television mastery.Thanks to wikipedia for additional information for this review.
