reviewText: This 2006 Image Entertainment release of the complete 156 episodes of the original Twilight Zone is a fitting tribute to this remarkable,engaging and classic TV Show.It also could be said that this is everything you ever wanted to know about the show and so much more.With space restrictions I cannot possibly list everything that is available to you but I will highlight some of them for you and hopefully in doing so whet your appetite:All shows have been remastered from the original film elements and look wonderfully crisp and clean throughout,the majority of eps have special features built into them like interviews with various writers and producers,commentaries by actors who appeared in them and isolated music scores,a special features area on the last disc of every season,almost all previews of next weeks' show by Serling have been reinserted into each ep along with the original endings c/w end commercials(!),there are many tv clips showing Rod Serling appearing on other various shows of the times like Jack Benny,Garry Moore,Groucho Marks,etc.,filmed excerpts from a writers quorum he hosted,audio excerpts from a Sherwood Oaks College lecture series,the 1995 Amercian Masters Rod Serling tribute,and on and on.The dearth of material at your disposal within these discs is absolutely astounding and Image has done this series proud and it will be a benchmark that will stand for years to come.If you own Mark Zichree's wonderful book "The Twilight Zone Companion"(I have the original /82 edition)it is easy to think you "know it all",but let me tell you that is NOT the case.With or without the book there is just so much to see and learn here that you will come away with a whole new understanding and appreciation for not only the series itself but the man behind the show,Mr.Rod Serling.I just finished viewing all the eps and look forward to viewing all the extras(which might take as much time as the shows themsleves!),but I made a slight exception to my rule this time around.I viewed one special feature in the collection which was Serlings' early 60's interview with Mike Wallace.At one point Wallace all confident and pompous tells/asks Serling that he guesses that with the new series coming up(Twilight Zone) he was no longer going to be writing anything important or relevant.I felt like putting my hand through the screen and giving Wallace a shot upside the head.But surprisingly and to his credit,Serling comes back at him and tells him what he thinks of the comment.The interview reveals much of Serling's abilities as a writer,thinker and as a man;in spite of Wallace.The first three seasons are all half hour shows,the fourth are one hour shows and the fifth went back to a half hour.The fourth season to me tried to emulate The Zone's "rival" "Alfred Hitchcock Presents"(same time frame) but ended up for the most part a little too stretched at times.Openings for the seasons are as follows:1)a barren desert landscape/Dali-esque in look,2)The setting sun,3)The moving spiral,4)the moving clock and 5)The door.It is certainly true that not every ep is good.There is a wide range of quality in this series running the gamut from excellent to poor.But when the series hit the mark,which it did quite often,it really hit home and stayed in one's memory.Some classics for me are ones such as Time Enough At Last,The Monsters are Due on Maple Street,Walking Distance,Death's Head Revisited,Eye of the Beholder,Living Doll,The Nick of Time,The Masks,You Drive,and so many more.And of course some contain bloopers of which Mark Zichree in his book mentions,but I found a couple not mentioned anywhere.In "Death Ship" there is a main control panel in the background behind the ships' steering controls.About 3/4 the way through you will see a "shoulder"(something dark)suddenly move out from behind the panel and back in.A little later you will see shadows above this area flicker and move around.In "90 Years Without Slumbering" Ed Wynn stars as a grandfather who lives with his pregnant granddaughter and husband and who thinks he must keep winding an old grandfathers' clock or die.The blooper comes when Wynn makes direct reference to the fact that his granddaughter must look after his "grandson".It wouldn't be his grandson but his great-grandson!You will also hear,especially in the first season,some eps that contain the whirring of cameras in the background.I wasn't looking for them,but if you're so inclined,see how many you can find.Image has put all discs into(I found)very tight and thick plastic holders,which open like pages of a book.I found myself getting a little nervous sometimes taking them out as I couldn't get a proper grip from the outside edges and had to resort to pushing them from the underneath spindle to raise them a little.But after a while I got used to it and never had a slip up.Also long term this is good as you can be confident that these discs will not move around on you if you transport them anywhere.The packaging is also worthy of note.Each seasons' covers and backs, along with the entire case the set sits into,is slightly holographic in nature and when moved in the right way illicits some pretty neat colours and effects.All in all this set is every bit worth its' cost.It IS expensive I know and I put off getting this set for all this time because of that.I read the reviews over,finally made the plunge and have not regretted it one iota.This set WILL stand the test of time and it is a great testament to one of the best series ever to air on television.Its themes are Sci-Fi,fantasy,the occult,etc.,but they all give the illusion of reality and come with a patented bizarre twist near the end to send the message home.And don't for a minute think there are no messages in these shows as this genre is the perfect medium to disguise race relations,hatred,conformity and any of a myriad of other foibles of the human condition.But to me this is just the pleasant off shoot of what these shows really are;fabulous and thought provoking entertainment.If you have been holding back getting this set for whatever reasons,let me asure you you will not be disappointed in your purchase.If you have never seen this series,you also will not be disappointed and will enter into a wonderful journey and experience you will never forget.This is one of television's shining moments and we have Rod Serling and company to thank for it.
summary: A comprehensive and most fitting tribute to The Twilight Zone

reviewText: In the 50's and 60's American TV had a lot of anthology shows like Playhouse 90, Alfred Hitchcock Presents, One Step Beyond, Outer Limits, The Dick Powell Show, and US Steele Hour (to name just a mere few) but none have had more enduring popularity than the original TZ! These anthology shows would of course week after week have all new and different characters in totally different situations! TZ right from its first ep (Where is Everybody produced by William Self) was a genuine gem of suspense and scare tactics! The first three seasons were the show's best and (except for the pilot) were highly successfully produced by Buck Houghton (Rod Serling served as show host and writer of many, many superb eps)! Later the supernatural/horror/sci-fi anthology goes from half-hour to hour and Herbert Hirschman successfully produces these eps at first with Bert Granet picking up the slack for the last third of the fourth season eps (and doing almost as well as Hirschman did)! Granet leaves the show after it reverted back to a half-hour format in season 5 and producer William Froug takes the show from there and sadly Froug does indeed produce inferiorly to all his predecessors. (Serling's hand at writing was shaky by season 5 from having written so very much for four years and his last scripts, like Mr. Garritty and the Graves, rely more on great acting by the guest stars than the now rather sloppy writing to carry them!) Still overall the series was a very legendary classic!
summary: Perhaps the single best anthology series ever

reviewText: "The Twilight Zone: The Complete Definitive Collection" is just that! This set is one of the best DVD box sets on a classic television series ever put together and all other "Twilight Zone" collections pale in comparison to this splendid and marvelous set. The price itself is also amazing when you consider fans shelved out hundreds of dollars to own "The Twilight Zone" on VHS, as well as around $80.00 for individual season sets. Here you get all five seasons worth of shows, all 156 episodes that are uncut with their original network openings along with Rod Serlings' "preview for next weeks episodes" tags that were cut from their syndicated airings.The shows themselves look impeccable being cleaned and restored from their network CBS master copies and the sound is wonderful.The bonuses are great as well with audio commentaries on certain episodes from different actors and writers who worked on "The Twilight Zone". There is also an array of interviews that offer insights into the making of this television classic.If your reading this review you must be an ardent "Twilight Zone" fan. Your DVD collection will not be complete without this extraordinary collection. If your curious on the series remember "The Twilight Zone" has been made in many different forms since the original went off network televison in 1964. Movies and new series remakes have been made, but all pale to this original series that ran from 1959-1964. Like "Star trek" that came after it, "The Twilight Zone" was never a hit in the Nielsen ratings, but the critics loved it for its original scripts and innovative storytelling. Today, many college campuses throughout the country offer courses in dramatic writing, televison directing, and producing using these "Twilight Zone" episodes as examples for study.Out of all the episodes made of this series, many are standouts including "Eye of the Beholder", "Uncle Simon" (my personal favorite due to Rod Serling's writing), "The Midnight Sun", "Nightmare at 20,000 Feet", "Time Enough At Last", "Living Doll", "It's A Good Life", and Time magazine's all-time favorite "The Monster's Are Due On Maple Street".There is also an excellent book available on the making of "The Twilight Zone" called "The Twilight Zone-Unlocking The Door To A Television Classic". This is an exceptional piece of work due to the care and time invested by its author. The best part is the chapter dealing with all the individual episodes that includes airdates, production schedules, shooting locales, budget costs, salaries, and more. This softcover gem is fastly going-out-of-print so garb a copy as soon as you see one available. The price is a bit high, but it's worth the cost especially if your a huge "Twilight Zone" fan like me.Important to note too is the fact that CBS is releasing season one on Blue-ray on September 14, 2010 making "The Twilight Zone" one of the few 1960's TV series being made available in this new format.
summary: "Seeing "The Twilight Zone" Like You've Never Seen It Before"

reviewText: And now for something completely different...I'm not going to review "The Twilight Zone Complete Definitive Collection" here. If you're a fan of the late Rod Serling's groundbreaking science fiction/fantasy television series, you'll want to own this set, no questions asked, especially at Amazon's great tax-free price. Rather, let me simply say how I came to purchase this set, and maybe address a few practical questions that some buyers may have.I first saw "The Twilight Zone Complete Definitive Collection" DVDs in a Sam's Club. Sam's sold each of the five seasons separately, not in a boxed set like this Amazon version, at $29.95 per season (of course prices may change, but do the math). Each DVD in each of the full-season packages at Sam's was in its own slim-line snap-case, like the original full-season release of "Firefly--The Complete Series," which is probably the best way to secure and protect the DVDs. The thickness of the packages varied depending on whether the season contained five or six DVDs.Based on reading a couple of other reviews here before I ordered, I knew Amazon's set came in different packaging. Each season package is the same thickness, regardless of how many DVDs it contains. In each case, you'll find a central "page" with two overlapping DVDs, plus two DVDs in the back hinged panel and either one or two in the front panel. There's also a handy fold-out printed guide to what's on each DVD. Sometimes DVDs in this type of case can come loose and rattle around inside, possibly getting badly scratched. That definitely isn't the case with this set, at least in my experience. The DVDs are latched in place on their central spindles very securely. Removing them takes some effort, and requires pressing down on the spindle firmly while gently pulling up on the edges of the DVD at the finger cutouts in the case. Even though it seems that they might snap in half, that's probably unlikely, but it's a good idea to be as careful as possible.I don't know why Sam's and Amazon have two differently packaged sets of "The Twilight Zone Complete Definitive Collection." I can't compare them season-by-season to determine whether the special features are the same or not. They seem to be, but I can't be sure. In any event, with 28 DVDs, 156 episodes, loads of extras and a great price, every fan of the series should own this set. Enjoy!
summary: Just a Few Words About the Packaging

reviewText: DVD REVIEW: Upscaled on my blu-ray player, it's almost as clear as it probably would be on blu-ray. Some of the shadows are a little muddy, but it's not overly distracting. The only real annoying parts are those where moire gets a bit much (such as the coat of Mr. Simpson in "The Hunt"), but it doesn't happen too often.I like that each episode has Rod Serling promos for 'next week's episode' as well as some old commercials. I wish there were a 'play all' option in the menu so I could watch it when I'm immobilized during apheresis @ the Red Cross. The cases for each season are almost twice as thick as my blu-ray cases that have the same # of discs, but I have some DVD sets that are as big & only hold 2-3 discs, so it's not bad for the format. The box the season's come in is pretty solid and looks good.My advice is to get this, if you love TZ, but quickly inspect all the discs. There are 5-6 discs in each season's case and some genius came up with the idea of gluing foam pads on the center flap to keep it from making noise. The problem is that in all but one case, the pads were glued mostly to the discs & 1 disc was popped loose. The loose disc was slightly scratched (the glue pad forced it against the holder), but luckily but it hasn't caused any problems. If you do get a defective one, Amazon has been great with every problem I've ever had & I know would quickly exchange it.Update: Blu-ray REVIEWThey had a sale, so I decided to bite the bullet & upgrade to Blu-ray. Turns out my father-in-law loves TZ, so I gave hime the DVDs. The Blu-rays have a "play all" option (yea!) The highlights & shadows are so much clearer than on the DVDs and there weren't any of those annoying glue pads. Of course the BR cases take up less space as well.All the same commercials are on the BR, and it gives you an option of watching with the original or enhances sound. This set also includes radio broadcasts you can listen to if you like that. (I checked on out, but I'll go back to those after I finish watching the set) The audio on the radio, as well as TV versions, is beautifully clean & clear. I have no complaint about the DVD quality, but there is a major difference in the BR. If you want the best & don't mind paying twice, upgrade. If you're buying for the first time & don't have a BR player, this might be the incentive you need to get one.
summary: So much better on blu-ray. Glad I upgraded.
